Description.val: MK XIIA Mode 5 provides improved secure cooperative combat identification via Identification Friend or Foe (IFF).  MODE 5 is a product improvement which is designed to be installed through engineering changes to digital MK XII interrogators and transponders including, but not limited to the APX-118/123, UPX-37/41C, APX-111, and APX-119.  Mode 5 is designed to be installed in all Navy Type/Model/Series aircraft which are currently Mode 4 IFF capable.  Mode 5 is developed in cooperation with North Atlantic Treaty Organization and is governed by STANAG 4193.

Name.@footnote: The support lines in the APN budget increase to address additional software and hardware modifications for new platforms.  The program supports additional type/model/series implementations for Mode 5 in FY14.  Many of those platforms (C-130, C-20, C-40, E-6B, UC-35) require specific configurations that affect support costs.

The support lines in the APN budget increase to address additional software and hardware modifications for new platforms.  The program supports additional type/model/series implementations for Mode 5 in FY14.  Many of those platforms (C-130, C-20, C-40, E-6B, UC-35) require specific configurations that affect support costs.

The support lines in the APN budget increase to address additional software and hardware modifications for new platforms.  The program supports additional type/model/series implementations for Mode 5 in FY14.  Many of those platforms (C-130, C-20, C-40, E-6B, UC-35) require specific configurations that affect support costs.

The support lines in the APN budget increase to address additional software and hardware modifications for new platforms.  The program supports additional type/model/series implementations for Mode 5 in FY14.  Many of those platforms (C-130, C-20, C-40, E-6B, UC-35) require specific configurations that affect support costs.

Mode 5 IFF "A" Kits will be required for installation on the F/A-18C/D, C-130T, C-20, C-40, E-6B, and UC-35 platforms along with the "B" kits. The other platforms will only require "B" kits. A-Kit realignment due to changes in platform schedules.  A-Kits are only required for certain platforms.  Many of our platforms to date have been upgrades of APX-118s to APX-123s (form, fit replacement in the aircraft).  However, some other platforms (F/A-18C/D and C-130T are two examples) do require A-kit modifications.  The A-Kit unit prices vary from platform to platform based on the implementation required to achieve the Mode 5 capability.

B-Kit unit cost varies based on equipment procured in a given year.  Many of the current procurements have been APX-123 modification kits.  Platforms will require either APX-111, APX-119 or APX-123 modification kits. The APX-111 modification kits start to be procured in FY13 though have a ramp in quantities in FY14.

B-Kit NRE increases in FY15 and FY16 support aircraft ECPs on C-130T, AV-8B, and various commercial derivatives. Platform ECPs vary in cost as will the B-Kit NRE for specific platform implementation.  Additionally, each platform ECPs requires data and other elements which also vary.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Field Installs kits and Vendor Depot ECP Install

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  MK XIIA Mode 5 provides improved secure cooperative combat identification via Identification Friend or Foe (IFF).  Mode 5 upgrades existing Mode 4 IFF equipment, including cryptography, support equipment, and associated hardware and software changes.  Mode 5 is designed to be installed through engineering changes to digital MK XII interrogators and transponders including, but not limited to the APX-118/123, UPX-37/41C, APX-111, and APX-119.  Mode 5 is designed to be installed in all Navy Type/Model/Series aircraft which are currently Mode 4 IFF capable.  Mode 5 is developed in cooperation with North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and is governed by STANAG 4193.  (ORD # 577-06-01).

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  MODE 5 completed a brassboard development in December 1997.  Modeling and simulation to demonstrate interoperability was completed in February of 1998 to support NATO STANAG development.  Proof of concept flight testing completed in December 1999.  A Preliminary Design Review for the proposed Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) to incorporate MODE 5 in the APX-118 was completed in July 2001.  Contracts for prototype Cryptographic Module and ECP kit are presently executed.  Milestone B was completed in 3QFY03.  Operational Assessment completed 2QFY06. Milestone C and Low Rate Initial procurement was approved in July 2006. In March 2007, Joint Requirements Oversight Council Memorandum (JROCM 047-07) endorsed a Mode 5 Joint Initial Operational Capability in FY14 and Joint Full Operational Capability in 2020. A successful IOT&E was held 1QFY12.  Full Rate Production was approved 4QFY12.
